This assessment encourages students to actively engage with weekly class discussions and lecture content. Students will respond in writing to discussion questions during class time. Each response should demonstrate understanding of the topic and provide a thoughtful, original perspective. Responses will be brief (approximately 100–150 words) and completed within the allocated time during class.

Students may choose any five sessions from Weeks 2–13 to complete this task. Each submission will be collected at the end of the class. Late submissions will not be accepted, as this task is designed to assess real-time engagement.

Responses will be marked based on relevance, clarity, and originality. Any copied or AI-generated content will result in zero marks and may be referred to the School’s Integrity Officer.

assessments.task_description:
This assessment deepens engagement with core readings and connects them to lectures and class discussions.

Students will complete five submissions based on designated readings from Weeks 3, 5, 8, 10, and 12. The readings are marked in the course reading list as "Required" and "Reading Summary and Reflection item".

Task (≈400 words per submission)

  • Summary (≈150 words): Summarise the author’s central argument and key concepts in your own words.
  • Reflection (≈250 words): Respond to two or more guiding prompts and include one quote from the reading (with page number) that you analyse in context.
  • Guiding prompts (choose ≥2):
  1. How does the reading relate to this week’s lecture and class discussion?
  2. Which examples from Korean popular culture (e.g., K-pop, drama, film, fandom, webtoons, streaming) support or challenge the author(s)’s claims?
  3. Do you agree or disagree with the author’s perspective? Why?
  4. How does the reading help explain broader themes in Korean society and culture?

Each submission is due online by Friday of the following week (e.g., Week 2 reflection due Friday of Week 3 at 5 pm). Submissions will be marked based on accuracy, relevance, and originality.

STATEMENT ON AI & MT

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

assessments.task_description:
The In-Semester Essay will be completed in person during Week 6 in your regular classroom and scheduled class time at 10am. This assessment allows you to demonstrate your understanding of course concepts and readings. The exam is closed-book; no notes, textbooks, or electronic devices are permitted.

The essay question will require you to respond to a discussion prompt using quotes from the assigned readings provided in the exam paper. Your answer should be approximately 600–800 words and include analysis that connects readings to lecture content and class discussions.

Essays will be marked based on clarity of argument, integration of readings, and depth of analysis.

Note: The In-Semester Exam is a hurdle requirement. Students must attempt this exam to pass the course. Failure to sit the exam will result in a maximum final grade of 3 for the course, regardless of performance in other assessments.

assessments.task_description:
For the Final Essay, students will choose one question from a list provided in Week 13 and write a 2,000-word (+/-10%) essay. The essay should incorporate lecture materials, class discussions, and at least three references from the course reading list. Proper APA referencing is required.

In addition, students will submit a 3-minute video reflection (5%) explaining the key argument of their essay and how their understanding of Korean popular culture has evolved throughout the course. The video should be uploaded with the essay by the due date.

Essays will be marked based on argument clarity, integration of course materials, and originality. The video will be assessed on clarity, engagement, and depth of reflection.
